results.title: A Nous la Liberte = Freedom for Us
results.brief_description:
Two convicts, Louis and Emile, escape from prison, but Emile is recaptured. Louis makes his way into the world and advances from gramophone salesman to owner of a huge, modern gramophone factory. When Emile is released, he joins is old cellmate at the plant. After things go wrong, they take to the road together as tramps. Clair has created a sublime musical comedy satire on the work ethics and the dehumanizing effects of mass-production techniques. The film inspired Chaplin’s ‘Modern times’, in which there are similar sequences on the assembly line. Danger in ‘A nous la liberte’ often comes in the form of prophetic images of militaristic domination: the factory guards wear proto-fascist armbands and uniforms. The film equates authoritarianism with capitalist exploitation of the working class. Emile’s one time fellow prisoner, Louis becomes a wealthy industrialist and builds a factory modelled on the prison from which he once escaped. But Emile is the Dada remedy to Louis’s capitalist order. Everywhere he goes, straight lines collapse in confusion and mass production comes to a standstill.” Reference: Alan Williams. ‘Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking’. Harvard University Press, 1992.

Credits: Producer, Frank Clifford ; director, Rene Clair ; writer, Rene Clair ; photography, Georges Perinal ; music, Georges Auric ; art direction, Lazare Meerson.
Cast: Raymond Cordy, Henri Marchand, Rolla France, Paul Olivier, Jacques Shelly, Andre Michaud.

results.title: A Place in the sun
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Musser, University of California, Los Angeles and Junior League of San Francisco
results.brief_description: This film reveals the work being accomplished by doctors and specialists working in schools especially for the treatment of cerebral palsy. Children are seen being helpted to improve their muscular co-ordination and learning to do things for themselves such as putting on shoes, doing up buttons, and handling a knife and fork. Shows through patient handling by their instructors, the children are enabled to return to their own homes where the treatment is carried on by their parents under supervision.

results.title: A Place in the country: Renfrewshire Regional Park
results.creator_credit: David Lewis, Films of Scotland and Tree Films
results.brief_description: Describes the first country park to be established in Scotland. Different groups of people are seen visiting the park: a family picnic party, a young couple going for a walk, two hikers and a party of school children. A regatta at Castle Semple Loch is shown. The film shows the range of attractions the park holds for all.

results.title: A Pinto for the Prince
results.creator_credit: John Spotton, Colin Low, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In 1977, Prince Charles was inducted as honorary chief of the Blood Indians on their reserve in southwestern Alberta. The ceremony, conducted in the great Circle of the Sun Dance, commemorated the centennial anniversary of the original signing of Treaty 7 by Queen Victoria.

results.title: A Night to remember [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Sidney Hayers, Roy Baker, William MacQuitty and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description: The dramatic story of the first sailing and sinking of the ocean liner, “Titanic” in 1912. “RMS Titanic”, the liner they said was unsinkable, struck an iceberg and sank with the loss of 1500 lives. The film faithfully depicts the heroism and horror of the night the unthinkable happened. Starring Kenneth More, Laurence Naismith and David MacCallum as the radio operator. From the book by Walter Lord.

results.title: A Night on the town
results.creator_credit: Judith de Paul, John Vernon, BBC and Brent Walker Film Productions
results.brief_description: A theatre production of music, song and dance filmed without an audience, “A Night on the town” is a foray into the world of nightclubs in Berlin, London, New York, New Orleans and Paris through a nostalgic recreation of the thirties. It features the music of Irving Berling, Noel Coward, Cole Porter and George Gershwin (An American in Paris) performed by the BBC Concert Orchestra, conducted by Alexander Faris. The cast includes Hinton Battle, Lewis Collins, Frank Gorshin, Eartha Kitt, John Moffatt, Elaine Paige, Ann Reinking, Bobby Short along with the Ambrosian Chorus. Staged and choreographed by Terry Gilbert with guest choreography Irving Davies (An American in Paris).

results.title: A Night in Casablanca
results.creator_credit: Archie Mayo, David Leow and Louis Vista Productions
results.brief_description: The setting for this inspired piece of Marx mayhem is the fabulous Hotel Casablanca in North Africa, where the hotel managers are dropping like flies. Each one is being murdered as he innocently blunders onto the stolen jewels and art treasures hidden in the hotel by a gang of escaped Nazis. Enter Groucho as the new manager, with Chico as his self-appointed bodyguard, aided and abetted by Harpo, the mischevious valetto villainous gang leader, Sig Rumann, and pandemonium quickly ensues. In their last important film together, the Marx Brothers are pulled into one crazy situation after another. The many plot twists put the boys through their hilarious paces, building the action to a sustained frenzy, and culminating in an outrageous chase scene complete with airplane acrobatics.

results.title: A Night at the opera
results.creator_credit: Sam Wood, Irving G. Thalberg and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: This original comedy with sparkling dialogue, delightful music and of course the Marx brothers, is one of the funniest to come from the MGM studio. The action romps along at madcap pace as Groucho, Chico and Harpo go into the grand opera business in Italy, dash across the Atlantic and stage an opera in New York, that has the city on its ear. It is an opera such as has never been seen before. Rated: G

results.title: A New world below
results.creator_credit: Mike Mahoney, Barry Cowling, Rex Tasker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The extension of Canada’s coastal sovereignty to 322 km (200 miles), together with the increase in offshore oil and gas activity, has led to a dramatic increase in the demand for knowledge about the sea. The film highlights the work of the Atlantic Geoscience Centre, Bedford Institute of Oceanography, in Nova Scotia. Stunning visuals include rolling icebergs and undersea volcanoes. Research is shown to depend on both high-technology and patient, minute analysis.
